tools.name: code_execution
tools.description: This is a stateful code interpreter you have access to. You can use the code interpreter tool to check the code execution output of the code. Here the stateful means that it's a REPL (Read Eval Print Loop) like environment, so previous code execution result is preserved. You have access to the files in the attachments. If you need to interact with files, reference file names directly in your code (e.g., open('test.txt', 'r')). Here are some tips on how to use the code interpreter: - Make sure you format the code correctly with the right indentation and formatting. - You have access to some default environments with some basic and STEM libraries: - Environment: Python 3.12.3 - Basic libraries: tqdm, ecdsa - Data processing: numpy, scipy, pandas, matplotlib, openpyxl - Math: sympy, mpmath, statsmodels, PuLP - Physics: astropy, qutip, control - Biology: biopython, pubchempy, dendropy - Chemistry: rdkit, pyscf - Finance: polygon - Crypto: coingecko - Game Development: pygame, chess - Multimedia: mido, midiutil - Machine Learning: networkx, torch - others: snappy You only have internet access for polygon and coingecko through proxy. The api keys for polygon and coingecko are configured in the code execution environment. Keep in mind you have no internet access. Therefore, you CANNOT install any additional packages via pip install, curl, wget, etc. You must import any packages you need in the code. When reading data files (e.g., Excel, csv), be careful and do not read the entire file as a string at once since it may be too long. Use the packages (e.g., pandas and openpyxl) in a smart way to read the useful information in the file. Do not run code that terminates or exits the repl session. You can use python packages (e.g., rdkit, pyscf, biopython, pubchempy, dendropy, etc.) to solve chemistry & biology question. For each question, you should first think about whether you should use python code. If you should, then think about which python packages you need to use, and then use the packages properly to solve the question.

tools.name: browse_page
tools.description: Use this tool to request content from any website URL. It will fetch the page and process it via the LLM summarizer, which extracts/summarizes based on the provided instructions. Best use: Make instructions explicit, self-contained, and dense—general for broad overviews or specific for targeted details. This helps chain crawls: If the summary lists next URLs, you can browse those next. Always keep requests focused to avoid vague outputs.

tools.name: web_search
tools.description: This action allows you to search the web. You can use search operators like site:reddit.com when needed.

tools.name: x_keyword_search
tools.description: Advanced search tool for X Posts. Supports all advanced operators.

tools.name: x_semantic_search
tools.description: Fetch X posts that are relevant to a semantic search query.

tools.name: x_user_search
tools.description: Search for an X user given a search query.

tools.name: x_thread_fetch
tools.description: Fetch the content of an X post and the context around it, including parents and replies.

tools.name: view_image
tools.description: Look at an image at a given url or image id.

tools.name: view_x_video
tools.description: View the interleaved frames and subtitles of a video on X. The URL must link directly to a video hosted on X.

tools.name: search_pdf_attachment
tools.description: Use this tool to search a PDF file for relevant pages to the search query. Returns page numbers and text snippets.

tools.name: browse_pdf_attachment
tools.description: Use this tool to browse a PDF file. Returns text and screenshots of specified pages.

parameters.name: pages
parameters.description: Comma-separated and 1-indexed page numbers and ranges (e.g., '12' for page 12, '1,3,5-7,11' for pages 1, 3, 5, 6, 7, and 11)

tools.name: search_images
tools.description: This tool searches for a list of images given a description that could potentially enhance the response by providing visual context or illustration.

tools.name: conversation_search
tools.description: Fetch past conversations that are relevant to the semantic search query.

tools.name: post_tweet
tools.description: Post a new tweet (or reply/quote) using ClawnX. Requires Moltbook API key set in env.

tools.name: get_tweet
tools.description: Fetch a single tweet by ID or URL using ClawnX.

tools.name: search_tweets
tools.description: Search for tweets using ClawnX. Returns list of tweet objects.

tools.name: post_thread
tools.description: Post a thread using ClawnX. Provide list of strings for each tweet in thread.

tools.name: like_tweet
tools.description: Like a tweet using ClawnX.

tools.name: unlike_tweet
tools.description: Unlike a tweet using ClawnX.

tools.name: retweet
tools.description: Retweet a post using ClawnX.

tools.name: unretweet
tools.description: Undo retweet using ClawnX.

tools.name: follow_user
tools.description:
Follow a user by @handle
 or user ID using ClawnX.

tools.name: unfollow_user
tools.description: Unfollow a user using ClawnX.

tools.name: get_user
tools.description:
Get user profile by @handle
 using ClawnX.

tools.name: get_current_user
tools.description: Get profile of the authenticated account using ClawnX.

tools.name: get_home_timeline
tools.description: Get home timeline using ClawnX. Returns list of tweets.
